trans-unit.target: Iterators

trans-unit.source: .NET, .NET Core
trans-unit.target: .NET, .NET Core

trans-unit.source: Iterators
trans-unit.target: Iterators

trans-unit.source: Almost every program you write will have some need to iterate over a collection.
trans-unit.target: Almost every program you write will have some need to iterate over a collection.

trans-unit.source: You'll write code that examines every item in a collection.
trans-unit.target: You'll write code that examines every item in a collection.

trans-unit.source: You'll also create iterator methods which are methods that produces an iterator for the elements of that class.
trans-unit.target: You'll also create iterator methods which are methods that produces an iterator for the elements of that class.

trans-unit.source: These can be used for:
trans-unit.target: These can be used for:

trans-unit.source: Performing an action on each item in a collection.
trans-unit.target: Performing an action on each item in a collection.

trans-unit.source: Enumerating a custom collection.
trans-unit.target: Enumerating a custom collection.

trans-unit.source: Extending [LINQ](linq.md) or other libraries.
trans-unit.target: Extending [LINQ](linq.md) or other libraries.

trans-unit.source: Creating a data pipeline where data flows efficiently through iterator methods.
trans-unit.target: Creating a data pipeline where data flows efficiently through iterator methods.

trans-unit.source: The C# language provides features for both these scenarios.
trans-unit.target: The C# language provides features for both these scenarios.

trans-unit.source: This article provides an overview of those features.
trans-unit.target: This article provides an overview of those features.

trans-unit.source: Iterating with foreach
trans-unit.target: Iterating with foreach

trans-unit.source: Enumerating a collection is simple: The `foreach` keyword enumerates a collection, executing the embedded statement once for each element in the collection:
trans-unit.target: Enumerating a collection is simple: The `foreach` keyword enumerates a collection, executing the embedded statement once for each element in the collection:

trans-unit.source: That's all there is to it.
trans-unit.target: That's all there is to it.

trans-unit.source: To iterate over all the contents of a collection, the `foreach` statement is all you need.
trans-unit.target: To iterate over all the contents of a collection, the `foreach` statement is all you need.

trans-unit.source: The `foreach` statement isn't magic, though.
trans-unit.target: The `foreach` statement isn't magic, though.

trans-unit.source: It relies on two generic interfaces defined in the .NET core library in order to generate the code necessary to iterate a collection: `IEnumerable<T>` and `IEnumerator<T>`.
trans-unit.target: It relies on two generic interfaces defined in the .NET core library in order to generate the code necessary to iterate a collection: `IEnumerable<T>` and `IEnumerator<T>`.

trans-unit.source: This mechanism is explained in more detail below.
trans-unit.target: This mechanism is explained in more detail below.

trans-unit.source: Both of these interfaces also have non-generic counterparts: `IEnumerable` and `IEnumerator`.
trans-unit.target: Both of these interfaces also have non-generic counterparts: `IEnumerable` and `IEnumerator`.

trans-unit.source: The [generic](generics.md) versions are preferred for modern code.
trans-unit.target: The [generic](generics.md) versions are preferred for modern code.

trans-unit.source: Enumeration sources with iterator methods
trans-unit.target: Enumeration sources with iterator methods

trans-unit.source: Another great feature of the C# language enables you to build methods that create a source for an enumeration.
trans-unit.target: Another great feature of the C# language enables you to build methods that create a source for an enumeration.

trans-unit.source: These are referred to as *iterator methods*.
trans-unit.target: These are referred to as *iterator methods*.

trans-unit.source: An iterator method defines how to generate the objects in a sequence when requested.
trans-unit.target: An iterator method defines how to generate the objects in a sequence when requested.

trans-unit.source: You use the `yield return` contextual keywords to define an iterator method.
trans-unit.target: You use the `yield return` contextual keywords to define an iterator method.

trans-unit.source: You could write this method to produce the sequence of integers from 0 through 9:
trans-unit.target: You could write this method to produce the sequence of integers from 0 through 9:

trans-unit.source: The code above shows distinct `yield return` statements to highlight the fact that you can use multiple discrete `yield return` statements in an iterator method.
trans-unit.target: The code above shows distinct `yield return` statements to highlight the fact that you can use multiple discrete `yield return` statements in an iterator method.

trans-unit.source: You can (and often do) use other language constructs to simplify the code of an iterator method.
trans-unit.target: You can (and often do) use other language constructs to simplify the code of an iterator method.

trans-unit.source: The method definition below produces the exact same sequence of numbers:
trans-unit.target: The method definition below produces the exact same sequence of numbers:

trans-unit.source: You don't have to decide one or the other.
trans-unit.target: You don't have to decide one or the other.

trans-unit.source: You can have as many `yield return` statements as necessary to meet the needs of your method:
trans-unit.target: You can have as many `yield return` statements as necessary to meet the needs of your method:

trans-unit.source: That's the basic syntax.
trans-unit.target: That's the basic syntax.

trans-unit.source: Let's consider a real world example where you would write an iterator method.
trans-unit.target: Let's consider a real world example where you would write an iterator method.

trans-unit.source: Imagine you're on an IoT project and the device sensors generate a very large stream of data.
trans-unit.target: Imagine you're on an IoT project and the device sensors generate a very large stream of data.

trans-unit.source: To get a feel for the data, you might write a method that samples every Nth data element.
trans-unit.target: To get a feel for the data, you might write a method that samples every Nth data element.

trans-unit.source: This small iterator method does the trick:
trans-unit.target: This small iterator method does the trick:

trans-unit.source: There is one important restriction on iterator methods: you can't have both a `return` statement and a `yield return` statement in the same method.
trans-unit.target: There is one important restriction on iterator methods: you can't have both a `return` statement and a `yield return` statement in the same method.

trans-unit.source: The following will not compile:
trans-unit.target: The following will not compile:

trans-unit.source: This restriction normally isn't a problem.
trans-unit.target: This restriction normally isn't a problem.

trans-unit.source: You have a choice of either using `yield return` throughout the method, or separating the original method into multiple methods, some using `return`, and some using `yield return`.
trans-unit.target: You have a choice of either using `yield return` throughout the method, or separating the original method into multiple methods, some using `return`, and some using `yield return`.

trans-unit.source: You can modify the last method slightly to use `yield return` everywhere:
trans-unit.target: You can modify the last method slightly to use `yield return` everywhere:

trans-unit.source: Sometimes, the right answer is to split an iterator method into two different methods.
trans-unit.target: Sometimes, the right answer is to split an iterator method into two different methods.

trans-unit.source: One that uses `return`, and a second that uses `yield return`.
trans-unit.target: One that uses `return`, and a second that uses `yield return`.

trans-unit.source: Consider a situation where you might want to return an empty collection, or the first 5 odd numbers, based on a boolean argument.
trans-unit.target: Consider a situation where you might want to return an empty collection, or the first 5 odd numbers, based on a boolean argument.

trans-unit.source: You could write that as these two methods:
trans-unit.target: You could write that as these two methods:

trans-unit.source: Look at the methods above.
trans-unit.target: Look at the methods above.

trans-unit.source: The first uses the standard `return` statement to return either an empy collection, or the iterator created by the second method.
trans-unit.target: The first uses the standard `return` statement to return either an empy collection, or the iterator created by the second method.

trans-unit.source: The second method uses the `yield return` statement to create the requested sequence.
trans-unit.target: The second method uses the `yield return` statement to create the requested sequence.

trans-unit.source: Deeper Dive into
trans-unit.target: Deeper Dive into

trans-unit.source: The `foreach` statement expands into a standard idiom that uses the `IEnumable<T>` and `IEnumerator<T>` interfaces to iterate across all elements of a colleciton.
trans-unit.target: The `foreach` statement expands into a standard idiom that uses the `IEnumable<T>` and `IEnumerator<T>` interfaces to iterate across all elements of a colleciton.

trans-unit.source: It also minimizes errors developers make by not properly managing resources.
trans-unit.target: It also minimizes errors developers make by not properly managing resources.

trans-unit.source: The compiler translates the `foreach` loop shown in the first example into something similar to this construct:
trans-unit.target: The compiler translates the `foreach` loop shown in the first example into something similar to this construct:

trans-unit.source: The construct above represents the code generated by the C# compiler as of version 5 and above.
trans-unit.target: The construct above represents the code generated by the C# compiler as of version 5 and above.

trans-unit.source: Prior to version 5, the `item` variable had a different scope:
trans-unit.target: Prior to version 5, the `item` variable had a different scope:

trans-unit.source: This was changed because the earlier behavior could lead to subtle and hard to diagnose bugs involving lambda expressions.
trans-unit.target: This was changed because the earlier behavior could lead to subtle and hard to diagnose bugs involving lambda expressions.

trans-unit.source: See the section on [lambda expressions](lambda-expressions.md) for more information.
trans-unit.target: See the section on [lambda expressions](lambda-expressions.md) for more information.

trans-unit.source: The exact code generated by the compiler is somewhat more complicated, and handles situations where the object returned by `GetEnumerator()` implements the `IDisposable` interface.
trans-unit.target: The exact code generated by the compiler is somewhat more complicated, and handles situations where the object returned by `GetEnumerator()` implements the `IDisposable` interface.

trans-unit.source: The full expansion generates code more like this:
trans-unit.target: The full expansion generates code more like this:

trans-unit.source: The manner in which the enumerator is disposed of depends on the characteristics of the type of `enumerator`.
trans-unit.target: The manner in which the enumerator is disposed of depends on the characteristics of the type of `enumerator`.

trans-unit.source: In the general case, the `finally` clause expands to:
trans-unit.target: In the general case, the `finally` clause expands to:

trans-unit.source: However, if the type of `enumerator` is a sealed type and there is no implicit conversion from the type of `enumerator` to `IDisposable`, the `finally` clause expands to an empty block:
trans-unit.target: However, if the type of `enumerator` is a sealed type and there is no implicit conversion from the type of `enumerator` to `IDisposable`, the `finally` clause expands to an empty block:

trans-unit.source: If there is an implicit conversion from the type of `enumerator` to `IDisposable`, and `enumerator` is a non-nullable value type, the `finally` clause expands to:
trans-unit.target: If there is an implicit conversion from the type of `enumerator` to `IDisposable`, and `enumerator` is a non-nullable value type, the `finally` clause expands to:

trans-unit.source: Thankfully, you don't need to remember all these details.
trans-unit.target: Thankfully, you don't need to remember all these details.

trans-unit.source: The `foreach` statement handles all those nuances for you.
trans-unit.target: The `foreach` statement handles all those nuances for you.

trans-unit.source: The compiler will generate the correct code for any of these constructs.
trans-unit.target: The compiler will generate the correct code for any of these constructs.
